question: The client has her 19 year old grandchild living with her. She says she does her own thing and they don't really share food. Does the grandchild need to be included?
guru_cards: Who are mandatory HH members for food stamps?
derived_questions: Does the grandchild live with you?
Is the grandchild financially dependent on you?
Do you provide regular support for the grandchild?
Does the grandchild live with you?
Do you provide regular support for the grandchild?
Is the grandchild financially dependent on you?
Can children under 18 years of age ever.entire_card:
Can children under 18 years of age ever be certified as a separate household from other adults living in the home?
Answer:
Yes, if the adults with whom they are living do not exercise parental control or offer financial support. Clients who are officially emancipated usually fall under this category. If the client not entirely certain or it's close but messy we can error on the side of applying and inform the client the county will help them figure out the household if need be.
Example: Ms. G is 17 years old. She lives with her aunt. Ms. G works and purchases and prepares her own meals. When questioned about household composition she stated that her aunt does not exercise parental control over her. The case manager certifies Ms. G as a one-person household.
Food stamps only
Can children under 18 years of age ever.summary: If an adult living with a grandchild under 18 years old does not provide parental control or financial support, the grandchild can be certified as a separate household for food stamp eligibility determination.

derived_questions: Does the grandchild live with you?
Do you provide regular support for the grandchild?
Is the grandchild financially dependent on you?
Who are mandatory HH members for food st.entire_card:
Who are mandatory HH members for food stamps?
Answer:
The following household members are ALWAYS included, even if they report that they do not share/prepare meals together. (see text only below, see flow chart further down)
Spouses:
If living in the same residence
Children:
If age 17 or younger, the child is mandatory with legal guardian
If age 18-21, the child is mandatory if natural, adopted, or step child*
A mandatory child's own child or spouse would need to be included on the application as well
*Ex. If a 20 year old child resides with their parent, they would be mandatory.
*Ex. If a 20 year old child resides with their grandparent, they would NOT be mandatory. They would likely be sharing/preparing meals together, but are not required to be listed on the same SNAP application.
﻿
﻿
Who are mandatory HH members for food st.summary: The rules for mandatory household members for food stamps include children up to age 21 who live with their grandparents, but only if they are natural, adopted, or step children; otherwise, they would not be required to be listed on the same application.

derived_questions: Does the grandchild live with you?
Do you provide regular support for the grandchild?
Is the grandchild financially dependent on you?
In what cases can a parent who has a joi.entire_card:
In what cases can a parent who has a joint custody arrangement include a child on a food stamp application?
Answer:
(a) When the custody arrangement between parents is uneven, the child would be included in the household that provides the child with the majority of his or her meals.
(b) When there is an equal custody arrangement and the children eat 50 percent of their meals with each parent, the case manager must decide which household should include the child. If both parents apply and cannot agree on which household will include the child, the case manager will resolve the issue by including the child in the household that applied first.
Note: The case manager must insure that the child is included in only one household.
Food Stamps only
In what cases can a parent who has a joi.summary: In cases of joint custody arrangements for food stamp applications, the child is typically included in the household providing the majority of meals or the one that applied first if equal shares are met.

derived_questions: Do you provide regular support for the grandchild?
Can students be part of a SNAP household.entire_card:
Can students be part of a SNAP household?
Yes, however students must meet additional criteria to be part of the SNAP Household.
Students must meet one of the following conditions:
under age 18 or age 50 or older
Have a physical or mental disability
still in high school
responsible for the care of a dependent household member under age 6
responsible for dependent household member aged 6-11 without adequate child care and therefore cannot participate in job training or work requirements
Enrolled full-time and is a single parent with responsibility for the care of a dependent child under age 12, regardless of the availability of adequate child care
working at least 20 hours per week
receiving Temporary Cash Assistance benefits
are attending less than half-time
participating in on the job training
Can students be part of a SNAP household.summary: The eligibility of a grandchild living with a client for SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) depends on the grandchild's age, disability status, and other specific conditions.

What if a client does not want to provid.entire_card:
What if a client does not want to provide information about other household members?
We always want to try and collect as much information about everyone living in the household, but sometimes clients are not comfortable disclosing information about people living there who are non-applicants.
If a client is living with non-mandatory household members, it is helpful to include basic information. When other household members are not included, it can pose delays down the line when caseworkers uncover other household members. When we have an idea of the composition of the household, it allows for faster troubleshooting.
FOR FOOD STAMP BENEFITS
In scenarios where there are people who are
NOT in the client's SNAP household
(roommates/boarders/family members who share less than 50% of the grocery budget) ideally, you will want to collect full name, birth date, gender and marital status for everyone not applying.  You will
at least
need to collect names and approximate ages of other people in the household.
We can proceed with the application if the client is insistent about not including them. We should still leave a portfolio note explaining that other household members reside with the client, but the client requested they not be included.
For example: Client has 3 additional roommates, but requested they not be listed on the application. Client does not share a food budget with the other members and they are not mandatory household members.
What if a client does not want to provid.summary: When applying for food stamps, while it's ideal to provide information about all household members, clients can proceed without listing non-applicants residing with them, but leaving a note in their portfolio is recommended.

derived_questions: If they do have to list them, do we need to include the adult child's income?
Who are mandatory HH members for food st.entire_card:
Who are mandatory HH members for food stamps?
Answer:
The following household members are ALWAYS included, even if they report that they do not share/prepare meals together. (see text only below, see flow chart further down)
Spouses:
If living in the same residence
Children:
If age 17 or younger, the child is mandatory with legal guardian
If age 18-21, the child is mandatory if natural, adopted, or step child*
A mandatory child's own child or spouse would need to be included on the application as well
*Ex. If a 20 year old child resides with their parent, they would be mandatory.
*Ex. If a 20 year old child resides with their grandparent, they would NOT be mandatory. They would likely be sharing/preparing meals together, but are not required to be listed on the same SNAP application.
﻿
﻿
Who are mandatory HH members for food st.summary: Household members aged 18-21 who live with their parents and have their own income may be mandatory for food stamp applications depending on the relationship between the parent and child.

derived_questions: Do clients have to list their adult children living with them if they have jobs and buy their own food?
What if my client shares meals but wants.entire_card:
What if my client shares meals but wants to apply for food stamps on their own?
If a client expresses a desire to apply for SNAP separately from those they live and currently eat with, consider the following:
Is the client sharing meals only temporarily? (due to immediate necessity or a temporary living situation)
Is the client expressing a desire to use SNAP benefits only for themselves? (not other people they live with)
Is the client/their household willing to provide a signed statement to the county office that their intention is to eat/prepare meals separately from others that they live with?
If any of the above are answered
YES
and the other household members are
not mandatory
SNAP HH members, then the client can apply on their own. (Find the mandatory HH members here:
Who are mandatory HH members for food stamps?
)
PLEASE NOTE
We should never lead or encourage a client to apply themselves disingenuously, nor should we suggest to a client that defining their SNAP household in one way versus another would be better for them. The purpose of this clarification is to acknowledge that SNAP applicants who actively express a desire to receive and use SNAP for themselves only can be applied in this manner. We should explain the rule and allow the client to apply how they desire.
If the processing office has concerns or uncertainties about the SNAP household, they may ask the applicant(s) to supply verification (like a signed statement).
What if my client shares meals but wants.summary: If a client desires to apply for food stamps independently while their adult child resides with them and buys their own food, the client can do so as long as they provide a signed statement to the county office stating their intention to eat separately. However, the processing office may request verification if they have concerns or uncertainties about the household composition.

derived_questions: If they do have to list them, do we need to include the adult child's income?
What if the only eligible household memb.entire_card:
What if the only eligible household members are children under 18?
If all adults in the SNAP household are ineligible non-citizens, but have children who are eligible, the adult will still need to be listed as the head of household. Minors can not be listed as head of household.
The income/resources of the adult is still counted in these situations. The system will know how to count it to accurately determine eligibility.
What if the only eligible household memb.summary: In cases where only children under 18 are eligible SNAP household members, adults who are ineligible non-citizens must still be listed as heads of household, with their income and resources included for accurate eligibility determination.

derived_questions: Does the client share a kitchen with his roommates?

If a non-mandatory household (HH) member.entire_card:
If a non-mandatory household (HH) member already receives SNAP, and the client says they share & prepare meals, what steps should be taken?
Provide guidance and ask the following:
Do you know if you're included on that household member's SNAP application?
The SNAP benefit typically includes people who live in the same household and share/prepare meals together on the same application. Is there a reason that you were not included on the same case?
You can either have (household member) add you to the existing SNAP case or you can apply on your own. If you apply on your own, you would only be able to use the SNAP benefit for yourself and you would likely have to provide a written statement from (household member) stating that the two SNAP benefits would be used separately.
Please note that the above does NOT apply to mandatory HH members (spouses residing together, etc.)
If a non-mandatory household (HH) member.summary: If a client shares a kitchen and meals with roommates who are already on an SNAP case, they may need to consider being added to the existing case or applying separately while providing a statement from the roommates about separate use of benefits.

derived_questions: Do the roommates often cook and eat together in the shared kitchen?
Are live-in attendants included in food.entire_card:
Are live-in attendants included in food stamp households?
No, roomers and live-in attendants are not included as part of the food stamp household even if they share and prepare meals with the client. Live-in attendants can apply as a separate HH for their own food stamp benefits
Are live-in attendants included in food.summary: Despite sharing a kitchen and occasionally cooking and eating together, roommates are not considered part of the same food stamp household as the renter.

How is \"spouse\" defined for food stamp.entire_card:
How is "spouse" defined for food stamp applications?
Spouses are either of two individuals who:
Are married to each other under applicable state law; or
Are living together and are holding themselves out to the community as a married couple

derived_questions: Does the client live in an assisted living facility?
If a person is living in a household tem.entire_card:
If a person is living in a household temporarily, do they need to be included on the application?
In general, we should include everyone who is currently living with the household and will remain there during the duration of the application processing period (30 days from submission for SNAP/Medicaid).
If the client does not want to include the person, we can submit without them, but should leave a PRISM/TERRI AND submission note (if applicable) explaining that there is another individual temporarily living the house, but is not a countable applicant. This way if the administering agencies has questions about that individual, the case resolution team can troubleshoot more effectively.
Only pertains to non-mandatory household members.
If a person is living in a household tem.summary: A person residing in an assisted living facility who prefers to cook her own food instead of using the cafeteria is still required to include her in the food stamp application as a household member, but can leave a note explaining her temporary status if not a countable applicant.

Answer:
(a) When the custody arrangement between parents is uneven, the child would be included in the household that provides the child with the majority of his or her meals.
(b) When there is an equal custody arrangement and the children eat 50 percent of their meals with each parent, the case manager must decide which household should include the child. If both parents apply and cannot agree on which household will include the child, the case manager will resolve the issue by including the child in the household that applied first.
Note: The case manager must insure that the child is included in only one household.
Food Stamps only

and the other household members are
not mandatory
SNAP HH members, then the client can apply on their own. (Find the mandatory HH members here:
Who are mandatory HH members for food stamps?
)
PLEASE NOTE
We should never lead or encourage a client to apply themselves disingenuously, nor should we suggest to a client that defining their SNAP household in one way versus another would be better for them. The purpose of this clarification is to acknowledge that SNAP applicants who actively express a desire to receive and use SNAP for themselves only can be applied in this manner. We should explain the rule and allow the client to apply how they desire.
If the processing office has concerns or uncertainties about the SNAP household, they may ask the applicant(s) to supply verification (like a signed statement).
What if my client shares meals but wants.summary: If a client desires to apply for food stamps independently while temporarily sharing meals and intends to use benefits solely for themselves, they can do so as long as they provide a signed statement to the county office. However, it's essential not to encourage disingenuous applications or suggest defining SNAP households in one way over another. The processing office may request verification if there are concerns or uncertainties.

derived_questions: Does the client have custody of the child?
If a client receives less child support.entire_card:
If a client receives less child support than what is reported, what should be entered?
If the client receives an amount of child support that is less than the court ordered amount, we should enter the amount that the client actually receives.
The caseworker will have access to the court ordered amount and will likely ask the client about any discrepancies. Clients should be prepared to show proof (bank statement or letter from the provider showing the amount).
If a client receives less child support.summary: In determining whether to list a child on an application who primarily resides with the client but may also receive government assistance through their other parent, it is important for the client to disclose the actual received child support amount rather than the court-ordered amount.

derived_questions: Can the client and her husband apply for benefits without her parents' information?

What if a client does not want to provid.entire_card:
What if a client does not want to provide information about other household members?
We always want to try and collect as much information about everyone living in the household, but sometimes clients are not comfortable disclosing information about people living there who are non-applicants.
If a client is living with non-mandatory household members, it is helpful to include basic information. When other household members are not included, it can pose delays down the line when caseworkers uncover other household members. When we have an idea of the composition of the household, it allows for faster troubleshooting.
FOR FOOD STAMP BENEFITS
In scenarios where there are people who are
NOT in the client's SNAP household
(roommates/boarders/family members who share less than 50% of the grocery budget) ideally, you will want to collect full name, birth date, gender and marital status for everyone not applying.  You will
at least
need to collect names and approximate ages of other people in the household.
We can proceed with the application if the client is insistent about not including them. We should still leave a portfolio note explaining that other household members reside with the client, but the client requested they not be included.
For example: Client has 3 additional roommates, but requested they not be listed on the application. Client does not share a food budget with the other members and they are not mandatory household members.
What if a client does not want to provid.summary: If a client living with non-mandatory household members, such as her parents or older husband, is reluctant to disclose their information for food stamp benefits, the application can still be processed, but it may lead to delays and faster troubleshooting if their basic information is provided.

derived_questions: Can the client and her husband apply for benefits without her parents' information?

Can children under 18 years of age ever.entire_card:
Can children under 18 years of age ever be certified as a separate household from other adults living in the home?
Answer:
Yes, if the adults with whom they are living do not exercise parental control or offer financial support. Clients who are officially emancipated usually fall under this category. If the client not entirely certain or it's close but messy we can error on the side of applying and inform the client the county will help them figure out the household if need be.
Example: Ms. G is 17 years old. She lives with her aunt. Ms. G works and purchases and prepares her own meals. When questioned about household composition she stated that her aunt does not exercise parental control over her. The case manager certifies Ms. G as a one-person household.
Food stamps only
Can children under 18 years of age ever.summary: If the adults living together do not exert control or provide financial support, minors can be certified as separate households for benefit applications.

What if a client cannot apply for benefi.entire_card:
What if a client cannot apply for benefits by phone?
If we receive a notification from a client that they are unable to complete a screening by phone due to a disability, but still indicate an interest to apply, please alert your supervisor.
This will only occur if the client sends us a correspondence based on our outreach letter or insists while speaking with us that they are unable to complete the screening by phone and require a paper application or alternative means of applying.
CCS should print a paper application and include it with the following letter template. State specific information should be filled out on the letter.
Client Response Letter_Alternative Application Request _Final.docx
This letter and application response should only be used for clients who required an alternative accommodation versus expressing a preference. If the client indicates a preference for a paper application, BOS should still explain the benefits of completing a screening/application over the phone.
What if a client cannot apply for benefi.summary: In regards to the eligibility of a client and her husband for benefits while living with her parents, if they are unable to apply by phone due to a disability, an alternative application method can be provided upon request.

derived_questions: Can the client and her husband apply for benefits without her parents' information?
In what cases can a parent who has a joi.entire_card:
In what cases can a parent who has a joint custody arrangement include a child on a food stamp application?
Answer:
(a) When the custody arrangement between parents is uneven, the child would be included in the household that provides the child with the majority of his or her meals.
(b) When there is an equal custody arrangement and the children eat 50 percent of their meals with each parent, the case manager must decide which household should include the child. If both parents apply and cannot agree on which household will include the child, the case manager will resolve the issue by including the child in the household that applied first.
Note: The case manager must insure that the child is included in only one household.
Food Stamps only
In what cases can a parent who has a joi.summary: In cases of joint custody, if the clients' living arrangements and meal provisions do not align with the food stamp application guidelines for including a child in a particular household, they may need to consult with a case manager to determine eligibility.

What are the steps if the client is in a.entire_card:
What are the steps if the client is in a violent situation?
If a client explicitly expresses they are in a violent situation or you can clearly hear an altercation occurring, use the scripting below to navigate through the call.
If the client is not able to continue the call at this time or you overhear the violence escalating, alert your CCS immediately so they can assess how to proceed.
BASIC STEPS:
Notify a CCS and avoid holding - Slack to notify the CCS and Do your best to not put client on hold in order remain on the line with the client.
Post in the campaign channel if no CCS are available.
Anyone from the management team should be able to listen into the call and offer support
Confirm Intent -
Confirm the client’s intention with the scripting below
“Are you able to continue talking with me safely right now?"
NO-
If the Client states “No”  they’re unable to continue the call ask them in whichever order makes sense based on what you’re hearing:
Message
-
Alert a CCS immediately.
It is appropriate to interrupt a meeting in these instances.
Schedule a Callback: C
onfirm the best line to contact them on, what time/s and day/s are best and whether they would prefer to call us back
“Is there a better time to call you back?”
Confirm if Client needs Assistance:
use scripting below
“Are you in need of immediate assistance from authorities?”
For more information see the flow chart or full SOP below
YES
- If client states "Yes":
Collect contact information right away.
Offer referrals immediately.
If the client is in a state where they are able to continue the screening, you can continue with the application. Do not hesitate to ask for support.
Get guidance from your CCS on how to leave an appropriate note.
Take a break if needed.
PLEASE SEE FULL CLIENTS IN A VIOLENT SITUATION SOP FOR ADDITIONAL DETAILS
Clients in a Violent Situation SOP Text.pdf
Clients in a Violent Situation SOP Flow Chart.pdf
﻿
﻿﻿
﻿
What are the steps if the client is in a.summary: If a client expresses being in a violent situation or if an altercation is audible during the call, prioritize their safety by notifying a CCS and confirming their intent to continue the conversation before offering assistance or scheduling a callback.

derived_questions: How long has the client been an LPR herself?
When should a screening be started for a.entire_card:
When should a screening be started for a client who we have screened in the past?
Our standard is that a new screening should be started if:
we have not spoken to the client in the current calendar year
there are new/seasonal benefits that were not offered the last time we spoke to the client
If we are screening them for just new/seasonal benefits it's encouraged to do a full screening but bare minimum the new/seasonal benefits must be opened for a screening.
Example:
Client calls in July, we screened them in December the previous year. A new screening should be started.
Screenings should be started regardless if the client was previously closed out as a
hard or soft determination
. The reasoning is that eligibility guidelines tend to change in January so clients who were formally ineligible may be eligible at this time.
Note: If the client does not fall within these guidelines, but does indicate a need, they should be re-screened regardless of when we talked to them previously.
When should a screening be started for a.summary: A new screening for eligibility benefits is recommended if it's been a year since last contact with the client or if there are new/seasonal benefits available, as guidelines can change annually.

Who can complete an application on a cli.entire_card:
Who can complete an application on a client's behalf?
Anyone can complete a SCREENING on behalf of a client, but there are restrictions on who can complete an application for a client.
Benefit
States Affected
Rule
SNAP
PA, MD, NC, SC, MI, NY
Technically anyone calling in can complete an application for a client, but they must be listed as an AR so that they can then provide a telephonic signature.
Medicaid
PA, MD, NY
Person applying for Medicaid needs to agree to the R&Rs before application is submitted or an AR
Paper applications
PA, MD, NY
Anyone can go through the full application over the phone for paper application benefits since the actual application will be signed . (PTRR, HTC/RTC, SCRIE, DRIE, HEAP, HEAP Cooling)
Energy Assistance
PA, MD, NY
Person in the heating household must agree to the statements or an AR*
*EUSP Only
:  It is strong preferred that the primary account holder or spouse living in the same household agrees to the EUSP R&Rs.  In the case that the primary applicant /spouse is not able to do this, any adult (18+) may act as a proxy for EUSP and agree to the R&Rs. If a proxy is listed, they must fill out and submit a Proxy Authorization form
Extra Help/LIS
PA, MD, NY
Client, spouse, POA, family member, PA Medi (f. apprise) counselor
CCIS
PA
Parent/Caretaker or spouse
PACE
PA
Client, Spouse, AR, or family member can complete a PACE application
Who can complete an application on a cli.summary: In certain programs and states, an adult can act as a proxy to agree to the required statements on behalf of a client who is unable to do so themselves. However, specific rules apply regarding who can act as a proxy and how they must be listed in the application process.

If a client's spouse lives in a nursing.entire_card:
If a client's spouse lives in a nursing home and has Medicaid, but some or all of their income goes to the client. Does this count as income for SNAP?
Yes. There are special provisions which allow income from Nursing-home Medicaid recipients to go to their spouse living in the community. Therefore, this counts as the client's income, even though it is from their spouse residing in the nursing home;
If a client's spouse lives in a nursing.summary: In regards to SNAP eligibility, if a client and her boyfriend live together, have a child, and his income makes them ineligible, there may be special provisions for applying only the client's income based on specific circumstances. However, this can vary depending on the program rules.

What if the only eligible household memb.entire_card:
What if the only eligible household members are children under 18?
If all adults in the SNAP household are ineligible non-citizens, but have children who are eligible, the adult will still need to be listed as the head of household. Minors can not be listed as head of household.
The income/resources of the adult is still counted in these situations. The system will know how to count it to accurately determine eligibility.

If a person is living in a household tem.entire_card:
If a person is living in a household temporarily, do they need to be included on the application?
In general, we should include everyone who is currently living with the household and will remain there during the duration of the application processing period (30 days from submission for SNAP/Medicaid).
If the client does not want to include the person, we can submit without them, but should leave a PRISM/TERRI AND submission note (if applicable) explaining that there is another individual temporarily living the house, but is not a countable applicant. This way if the administering agencies has questions about that individual, the case resolution team can troubleshoot more effectively.
Only pertains to non-mandatory household members.
If a person is living in a household tem.summary: The application process for SNAP/Medicaid includes individuals who are currently living with the household and will remain there during the processing period, but temporary residents do not need to be included if they are not countable applicants. However, a PRISM/TERRI AND submission note should be added if the individual is present in the household but not listed as an applicant.

Who can complete an application on a cli.summary: In the context of assisting a 21-year-old client with an application, it is preferred but not strictly required for the primary account holder or an adult household member to provide mortgage payment information during the expenses step. However, they must agree to the program's requirements or designate an authorized representative to do so.

question: This household has everything! I can't keep everything straight and I don't remember who needs to be included. The client is married and they have two adult kids and then two foster kids. The client's mother lives with them and they have a live in attendant who takes care of her. One of the kids is 20 and in college full time. He's not working and comes home on summer and winter breaks. I think he's an ineligible student, but does he still need to be listed on the application, would he be included in the summer? Their other child is 23 and buys some of his own food, but will eat when his mother cooks a big dinner. The foster kids are 11 and 12. They eat with them, so I think they need to be included? The client's mother has special food needs so her live in attendant cooks for her separately and they eat together. She also wants to apply. How do I enter this?

What if a client does not want to provid.entire_card:
What if a client does not want to provide information about other household members?
We always want to try and collect as much information about everyone living in the household, but sometimes clients are not comfortable disclosing information about people living there who are non-applicants.
If a client is living with non-mandatory household members, it is helpful to include basic information. When other household members are not included, it can pose delays down the line when caseworkers uncover other household members. When we have an idea of the composition of the household, it allows for faster troubleshooting.
FOR FOOD STAMP BENEFITS
In scenarios where there are people who are
NOT in the client's SNAP household
(roommates/boarders/family members who share less than 50% of the grocery budget) ideally, you will want to collect full name, birth date, gender and marital status for everyone not applying.  You will
at least
need to collect names and approximate ages of other people in the household.
We can proceed with the application if the client is insistent about not including them. We should still leave a portfolio note explaining that other household members reside with the client, but the client requested they not be included.
For example: Client has 3 additional roommates, but requested they not be listed on the application. Client does not share a food budget with the other members and they are not mandatory household members.
What if a client does not want to provid.summary: In situations where clients prefer not to disclose information about non-applicant household members for food stamp benefits, it's essential to collect basic information when possible to ensure a smoother application process. However, if the client insists on excluding them, leave a portfolio note explaining their presence and the reason for their omission from the application.

In what cases can a parent who has a joi.entire_card:
In what cases can a parent who has a joint custody arrangement include a child on a food stamp application?
Answer:
(a) When the custody arrangement between parents is uneven, the child would be included in the household that provides the child with the majority of his or her meals.
(b) When there is an equal custody arrangement and the children eat 50 percent of their meals with each parent, the case manager must decide which household should include the child. If both parents apply and cannot agree on which household will include the child, the case manager will resolve the issue by including the child in the household that applied first.
Note: The case manager must insure that the child is included in only one household.
Food Stamps only
In what cases can a parent who has a joi.summary: In cases of joint custody arrangements, a child should be included in the household providing them with the majority of their meals. For complex situations involving multiple children and special food needs, it's essential to follow specific guidelines set by the case manager.

derived_questions: Are the foster kids included in family meals and should be listed on the application?
Does an applicant with foster children (.entire_card:
Does an applicant with foster children (or adults) need to include them on the food stamp application?
No, but they can choose to do so. If they choose to include foster children in the HH they may qualify for a larger benefit amount but must include the foster care payments they receive on behalf of the children as income.
Does an applicant with foster children (.summary: An applicant with foster children or adults can opt to include them in their food stamp application, potentially qualifying for a larger benefit amount while declaring any related foster care payments as income.

derived_questions: Are the foster kids included in family meals and should be listed on the application?
Who are mandatory HH members for food st.entire_card:
Who are mandatory HH members for food stamps?
Answer:
The following household members are ALWAYS included, even if they report that they do not share/prepare meals together. (see text only below, see flow chart further down)
Spouses:
If living in the same residence
Children:
If age 17 or younger, the child is mandatory with legal guardian
If age 18-21, the child is mandatory if natural, adopted, or step child*
A mandatory child's own child or spouse would need to be included on the application as well
*Ex. If a 20 year old child resides with their parent, they would be mandatory.
*Ex. If a 20 year old child resides with their grandparent, they would NOT be mandatory. They would likely be sharing/preparing meals together, but are not required to be listed on the same SNAP application.
﻿
﻿
Who are mandatory HH members for food st.summary: The household members who are mandatory for food stamps inclusion include spouses living in the same residence, children under 18 years old, and children aged 18-21 who are natural, adopted, or step children, along with their own children or spouses. Exceptions apply for those residing with grandparents.

derived_questions: Are the foster kids included in family meals and should be listed on the application?
Do foster care payments count as income.entire_card:
Do foster care payments count as income for food stamps?
Foster care payments count as unearned income if the household chooses to include the foster child/adult as a food stamp household member.
Do foster care payments count as income.summary: When considering whether to include foster kids in family meals and applications, remember that foster care payments can be classified as unearned income if the foster children are added as household members for food stamp eligibility assessments.

What if my client shares meals but wants.entire_card:
What if my client shares meals but wants to apply for food stamps on their own?
If a client expresses a desire to apply for SNAP separately from those they live and currently eat with, consider the following:
Is the client sharing meals only temporarily? (due to immediate necessity or a temporary living situation)
Is the client expressing a desire to use SNAP benefits only for themselves? (not other people they live with)
Is the client/their household willing to provide a signed statement to the county office that their intention is to eat/prepare meals separately from others that they live with?
If any of the above are answered
YES
and the other household members are
not mandatory
SNAP HH members, then the client can apply on their own. (Find the mandatory HH members here:
Who are mandatory HH members for food stamps?
)
PLEASE NOTE
We should never lead or encourage a client to apply themselves disingenuously, nor should we suggest to a client that defining their SNAP household in one way versus another would be better for them. The purpose of this clarification is to acknowledge that SNAP applicants who actively express a desire to receive and use SNAP for themselves only can be applied in this manner. We should explain the rule and allow the client to apply how they desire.
If the processing office has concerns or uncertainties about the SNAP household, they may ask the applicant(s) to supply verification (like a signed statement).
What if my client shares meals but wants.summary: If a client's mother with special food needs and their live-in attendant reside with them but eat separately, and the client desires to apply for food stamps individually, they should provide a signed statement to the county office affirming their intent to prepare and consume meals independently from other household members. The decision ultimately rests on the client's willingness to do so and the processing office's assessment of the situation.

derived_questions: How should the client's mother, who has special food needs, be entered into the application?
If a non-mandatory household (HH) member.entire_card:
If a non-mandatory household (HH) member already receives SNAP, and the client says they share & prepare meals, what steps should be taken?
Provide guidance and ask the following:
Do you know if you're included on that household member's SNAP application?
The SNAP benefit typically includes people who live in the same household and share/prepare meals together on the same application. Is there a reason that you were not included on the same case?
You can either have (household member) add you to the existing SNAP case or you can apply on your own. If you apply on your own, you would only be able to use the SNAP benefit for yourself and you would likely have to provide a written statement from (household member) stating that the two SNAP benefits would be used separately.
Please note that the above does NOT apply to mandatory HH members (spouses residing together, etc.)
If a non-mandatory household (HH) member.summary: In the case of a multi-generational household with a client, their mother requiring special food needs and various adult children and foster kids present, ensure clear communication regarding each member's SNAP eligibility and application status before proceeding with separate or combined applications.
